comments.commentBody:
Tonight at my granddaughter's bedtime we read together from "Who was Rachel Carson" - just one little thing we both did to make things better.

With the imminence of an administration that promises to Make America Great Again for those who would despoil our earth, we old-timers need to pass on to the rising generation what our heroes taught us.

If parents and grandparents push back like this, it will deprive the trumps of this world one of the things they most need for their misanthropic ideology to proper - an ignorant population.
The insecticides that replaced DDT were less effective than DDT.  People died because of Rachel Carson.  No doubt the birds think well of her.

@ Here
Seriously? DDT almost wiped out the Peregrine Falcon, the Brown Pelican, and gravely endangered Bald Eagles, Osprey, Great Blue Herons etc...
Would you want to live in a world without those majestic birds? I wouldn't.

DDT may be bad for humans as well as birds. A recent study found a fourfold increase in breast cancer risk among women who had been exposed to DDT in utero. http://press.endocrine.org/doi/10.1210/jc.2015-1841

Re: "The slide may have started in the W. years,..."

The slide started in the Reagan years; 2016 is the culmination of that long slow slide.
Sorry -"prosper" not "proper".

The division in these comments is about the role of punishment vs the role of accountability. Ms Clark has shown that she holds herself deeply accountable for her role in this crime. There is no repair for murder, but does punishment accomplish any sense of peace or healing for victims? Other countries limit incarceration time, even for the most serious crimes. Ms Clark has done the only repair she could: to be accountable and to dedicate herself to the wellbeing and growth of others. Is the sum of judgement only for the worst deed we've ever done? If we want an effective criminal justice system, it must include the possibility of growth and acts of reparation. Truth and reconciliation. Punishment is ultimately a futile  act, a form of violence in response to violence. It is ineffective and unfairly meted out. We need a radical transformation in our criminal justice system from punishment to containment of violent offenders and intensive efforts at restorative justice and accountability.
My god. This paper thinks the only crime are calling trannies men instead of women, refusing to pretend all illegals are saints and lack of respect for idiotic, sexist Muslims.

I am torn between the feelings of mercy,especially at this time of year,
and hard -heartdeness towards someone
who took part in a vicious attack which
cost two police officers and a bank guard
their lives.
granted she has had a remarkable turn around
in her life,but at least she has had a life.the three
men for whose deaths she was at least partly
responsible had no such chance and their
families have had to deal with immeasurable
grief.
I would wait at least five more years to make it
an even forty years served.a message must still
be sent that the murder,directly or indirectly,
of law enforcement officers is an outrage that
can not be tolerated in a civilized society.

@Frank:  Of all the comments here on all sides, the one I find least comprehensible is your statement:  "I would wait at least five more years to make it an even forty years served."  What in the world do a few years and an "even number" have to do with anything, here or anywhere?  That is just a contrived notion that is meaningless.  Far better for everyone to discuss the vast gap between benevolence and revenge as discussed by many.  I find it hardest to accept the vengeful statements; it feels more like blind anger than thoughtful or inward-contemplating commentary.  As a thought - Norway normally releases murderers after no more than 45 years, the thought behind this being that prison is for correcting people more than for punishing people.  The recidivism rate in Norway is far lower than in the US, and the prison conditions are far, far different - more humane and definitely designed for rehabilitation, not for reducing already-damaged individuals to the level of animals.  I understand the punishment argument and the rehabilitation argument, and do not need anyone to come up with the old line, "What if it were your family who were murdered?"  It is a very difficult decision everyone must make, personally and internally, not a mob decision.

Felony murder is traditionally part of the definition of the crime of murder.

So what's your point?

[[Sean New Orleans
Unclear from the article whether she shows remorse or not. Given that three people were murdered that day would remorse even matter?]]

Yes, of course remorse matters. If she were on the other end of the spectrum, still spouting nutty ideology, we wouldn't be having this discussion.

I can get behind the idea that murder in the commission of a robbery should mean life in prison, no parole. And I would like to see every wrongfully convicted person freed (and the flaws in that process corrected) before someone like Clark is let go.

But I think we should also be willing to examine our closely held beliefs and - occasionally - modify them.

"Any eye for an eye makes the whole world blind."
There are limits to everything. At this stage keeping her incarcerated basically serves to keep prisons full. Rationally, any damage done cannot be further mitigated by the status quo. Do not we the taxpayers have some say as the math has been played out to so many places to the right of the decimal point?

Remarkable and noble comment from the slain officer's son, Edward J. O'Grady III.

However it turns out, that man can hold his head up high.
Cuomo's actions reflect one who lives in an ivory tower and revers social theory over the lives of victims.  A sad and pathetic act by a sad and pathetic politician.
She is "fully aware that it is painful and difficult for those who lost loved ones that day." Wow. Talk about contrition and acceptance of responsibility.
Yeah, you're quoting her lawyer, not her.  I have no idea whether she's really achieved contrition and acceptance of responsibility.  But neither do you.

Jfd - that's an excellent legal point. Felony murder is malum prohibitum.

I remember serving as a fellow grand juror argued for nullification for a conspirator who did not intend a killing concomitant with a felony. I said, "Yes, it is murder under statute."

Her involvement was not legally the same as Shakur's. It's a difficult call. Gov. Cuomo deliberated long and hard about this, I am sure. He is a credit to the office, and his father.

The article is incomplete and does not give necessary background information. Judith Clarke and Kathy Boudin were the privileged white liberal females at this infamous crime. All the African Americans are still incarcerated or died in jail. The paradox is that it would be hard to find people who have benefited more from the white privilege they complain about or who abused their status within American society more than this group. (Although the white husband of Kathy Boudin is still incarcerated but alive).

Here are some bits & pieces. There is more but space is limited.

Judith Clarke's daughter, Harriet, is lecturer at Stanford in the creative writing program

Kathy Boudin’s father, Leonard Boudin was the nephew of Louis Boudin, influential Socialist, labor lawyer and professor of constitutional law at Yale University. His brother-in-law was influential left-wing journalist I. F. Stone. Boudin

Kathy Boudin’s brother, Michael Boudin, is currently a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, serving as chief judge 2001-2008.

Chesa Boudin, Kathy Boudin’s son was raised by "adoptive parents" Bill Ayers and Bernardine Dohrn, who, like his parents, were one-time members of the Weather Underground. In 2003, he graduated from Yale University. He spent his junior year at the University of Chile, funded by a Rotary International Ambassadorial Scholarship. He went to Oxford University on a 2003 Rhodes Scholarship & graduated from Yale Law School in 2011
Ah yes ! The parable of the Liberal. What's good for me is not for thee !
What is your ultimate point, please?
Do you understand the difference between accomplishment and what you call privilege?

I have an ethical and moral issue with this action that has nothing to do with Ms. Clark's evolution in prison.  For all of my adult life I have opposed the death penalty, and one of my core beliefs has been that those who commit the most heinous crimes could be imprisoned for life with no possibility of parole. I believe many have been swayed by this argument, and almost feel that when we commute the sentence of such a person we are violating a contract with those prior death sentence supporters.  Richard Speck is long dead, but Charles Manson and others are still incarcerated. Couldn't their sentences be someday commuted?  This good deed has a price.

I also have an ethical problem with the death penalty and agree with you that if people responsible for the death of police officers are not going to be executed, they should be held in prison for life.  The convict has the opportunity to make amends by performing services to other convicts.  She has not paid her debt to society and should not be permitted freedom because she has a wealthy family.
Paul:  A person whose sentence states, "Life in prison without the possibility of parole", is not eligible for parole or for commutation of sentence.

Keeping murderers in jail -- balances the scales of justice, --

and shows the value we place on the lives of those taken, by punishing those who take lives, for as long as we are able, and then when no longer able, we hand punishment off to someone more able who takes on the challenge

As for the costs, well, extract transplantable organs

THAT repays a debt to society, in some infinitesimal fraction, but is the best we can do

I guess, of all this, the most noteworthy part are the remarks of Officer O'Grady's son about bringing healing to Ms. Clark's daughter, Harriet.  Imagine a world in which his was the prevailing attitude.
I'd rather imagine a world in which the MURDER wasn't committed.

I was just blocks away from the crime scene in Nyack that day, returning to my newspaper office from covering a high school sports event. It was a chaotic period and I was quite sad about the loss of life, all for no reason. But Ms. Clark has paid her debt to society and, by all accounts, has turned into a good person, contrite and willing to become a part of society. Edward J. O'Grady III is a mensch for what he said. I agree It is time to let this woman spend the last years of her life in freedom. I think she knows what she did was wrong.

Cuomo is reprehensible.  Doubly so because he and his family go around with taxpayer provided security but he makes a heroine of a woman that helped murder two police and the Brinks guard. He should give up his security detail since he places such a low value on law enforcement officers.

Open your bitter heart. This man who was directly affected by her crime has.
" But, he said, “the release of Judith Clark will take no more away from me and will bring no more hurt to my life.”

He also wrote about Ms. Clark’s daughter, Harriet, a lecturer at Stanford, who was 11 months old when her mother was arrested. “She did no more to deserve her lot than my sisters and I did to deserve ours,” he wrote. “If it brings an end to the suffering that Harriet has to deal with every day, then perhaps I can be happy for both of them, and I can assure you, I’ll still be able to sleep at night.”

Alain Delaquérière contributed research.
So she must have know that there was going to be a robbery. They sometimes go bad and people get kill. She should get the electric chair. Better late than never.

@Jane: The article didn't really say anything about remorse.

It does say "her attitudes began to change". But there's no detail given.

Right, just read the webpage. She regrets here role - Forget it. She should stay in prison and serve here full sentence.

She should just say she's sorry, but she doesn't probably because she isn't.

Thanks to Governor Cuomo for making a difficult but proper decision to recognize rehabilitation -- a too often forgotten purpose of incarceration.  And my admiration and appreciation to Edward J. O'Grady III, who, from knowledge of his own irrevocable loss,  understands the suffering of the families of the incarcerated.  A society that chooses only vengeance is not much of a model.

The ONLY rehabilitation, is resurrection of the deceased

A society that does not revile murderers, is not much of a society
Is it a coincidence that the elephant slaughter reached its height when China began investing / buying land in Africa? Now its the pangolins and sharks that need our help, badly!

To paraphrase Freud, All man's striving in life is to regain the familiarity of youth. Never is that more so than among friends - especially friendships formed in youth.
An elderly minister friend of many years spoke of a parishioner he visited. Her husband had been a Dutch Army major in the East Indies during WW2. A cryptographer who didn't return to Europe after the war.
When he died, she was elderly, alone, and partially disabled by arthritis.
Yet, she followed a routine and stoically faced each day reassured by regular visits from an understanding minister. Eventually he retired and I visited her during a canvass. What a remarkable person! scintillating conversation. Filled with stories and interest. She was radiant and alive in the presence of someone who could relate to that period of history and the circumstances of its time.
I lived far away and was immersed in distracting work. So, I left word with my friends successor about the importance of visits. But, no one came. After a few months she gave up and died.
There are many definitions of "friend".
The one I like best is that a friend is a person who believes in you when you don't. But it can be more than a person.
My mother lived to 99+ (with no meds). She preferred solitude and her constant companion were the scriptures of her faith.
Friends are people, or can be activities, or pets that reunite us with our youth. For whatever we hold to be true is what we recall from our youth as the result of a friend.

Dr. Bill Thomas identified the perils of loneliness for elders 25 years ago during his time as a nursing home medical director in New York. Out of that came The Eden Alternative, his vision of how life can be different, and how companionship, meaning and growth impact an elder's well-being.
Today, The Eden Alternative is alleviating the suffering of lonely elders on five continents, and over a dozen countries.
Thank you, Paula Span, for shining a light on this plague of darkness.
